messages.text: #8 is especially interesting because the color of our plates & such affect our perception of taste: <http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2014/12/31/370397449/food-psychology-how-to-trick-your-palate-into-a-tastier-meal>

attachments.title: Food Psychology: How To Trick Your Palate Into A Tastier Meal
attachments.text: Ingredients and preparation matter in making a delicious dinner. But so do a lot of other external factors, from your mood to room lighting. Here, a guide to enhancing the pleasures of the plate.

Yeh! I was surprised by that! I just signed up for Pro about 10 minutes ago :smile:
wow 15% off Creative Cloud is :ok_hand::skin-tone-5:

Also, if you end up using CodePen _alot_, a Pro account lets you have private Pens, so no worries about anything client-related getting out in the open. As a perk with Pro accounts, you also get 15% off your Creative Cloud subscription and 6 months of InVision. Looking into it more…
<https://codepen.io/pro/perks>

Hey _Codie Types!_ If you’ve been going to Colin’s HTML/CSS/Bootstrap workshops, you’ve probably heard of *CodePen* by now.

They have a pattern library that collects design patterns and examples that the community has coded up and submitted. These are short and sweet examples of how you can implement these things yourself, some with relative ease, others more advanced.

Check it out!
<https://codepen.io/patterns/>

Hey all, also a heads up that Will is working on the migration this week, so he may be reaching out at random times with questions about file locations and whatnot.  Thanks ahead of time for helping him out if you get targeted.

messages.text:
Well Hello,
Check out this wonderful guide to Combining Typefaces: 
<http://blog.typekit.com/2016/04/29/combining-typefaces-free-guide-to-great-typography/>

attachments.title: Combining Typefaces: Free guide to great typography
attachments.text:
Originally published by Five Simple Steps in 2013, my Pocket Guide to Combining Typefaces has sold thousands of copies, been used in college curricula, and been cited in conference talks by industry-leading designers.
Unfortunately, Five Simple Steps closed its doors this month. Because this pocket guide is no longer available for purchase, I&rsquo;ve decided to make it available for free here on the Typekit blog. Download the PDF, and enjoy.
Download Tim Brown&rsquo;s Pocket Guide to Combining Typefaces (PDF).
Here&rsquo;s the official marketing material:

This very brief &ldquo;pocket guide&rdquo; is for designers and developers who want to make better choices about type and build their typographic expertise. Successful typeface combinations are partly a matter of good taste, which can be tough to develop. And finding typefaces that work well together often takes more time than we (or our managers, or our spouses!) think it should.
The guide will give you a framework for efficient practice, lead you to founts of knowledge, and help you judge the work you see, including your own work. It will also encourage you to be selective, patient, and reasonable, focusing on web contexts and your design goals.

Table of contents
Type: Some background on type and typography, covering designers, anatomy, families, classification, and the jobs that typefaces do.
Context: A brief look at web compositions as coordinated chunks of typeset elements, shifting among many states simultaneously.
Choosing typefaces: Strategies for selecting typefaces based on real design goals, to truly understand why a combination works or doesn&rsquo;t.
Judging combinations: Practical advice about identifying successful typeface combinations by using them and looking at them carefully.
Critique: An appraisal of five different sites&rsquo; type choices and typesetting, noting the relationships between their successes and the strategies and advice in this guide.
So go ahead, take a copy of my Pocket Guide to Combining Typefaces (PDF). I hope you like it. And if you do read it, please let me know what you think.
attachments.fallback: The Typekit Blog Link: Combining Typefaces: Free guide to great typography
